bibl.title: Letter from Robert Carter to William Dawkins, June 3, 1727

div1.p: Robert Carter writes to William Dawkins, June 3, 1727, to advise the London merchant of a bill of exchange drawn on him payable to George Braxton.

div1.head: Letter from Robert Carter to William Dawkins, June 3, 1727

opener.dateline:
Rappahannock, [Lancaster County, Virginia]
June the 3d: 1727
Mr. Willm: Dawkins

div1.p:
I writ to you Yesterday by Capt: Keeling
this Serves only to advise you that I have this day drawn upon you
for One hundred Eighty two pounds five and four pence pay
able to Colonel George Braxston which I desire you to answer
at Time and place to the Accot: of
div1.closer:
Yor: very humble Servt:
per the Dispatch Capt. Barry

div1.head: NOTES
div1.note: Source copy consulted: Robert Carter letter book, 1727 May-1728 July, Robert Carter Papers (acc. no. 3807), Albert and Shirley Small Special Collections Library, University of Virginia.

Robert Carter generally used a return address of "Rappahannock" for the river on which he lived rather than "Corotoman," the name of his home, on his correspondence, especially to merchants abroad. The county and colony have been added for clarity.
[1] Captain William Keiling commanded the Betty. (Survey Report 6800, Virginia Colonial Records Project, Albert and Shirley Small Special Collections Library, University of Virginia.)
